course_title: Mental Health & Justice & Working with the Community

learning_outcomes.description: Describe and advocate for the role of speech pathology to meet the everchanging needs of a community including mental health and justice.
Identify and develop evidence-based community health promotion and prevention activities to address social determinants of health inequity in speech pathology.

Critically reflect on social determinants and ways of knowing and being to support the development of culturally responsive services in collaboration with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, Elders and cultural leaders.
Advocate for interprofessional practice in managing people with communication and swallowing difficulties in the mental health, justice and community setting.
Describe the key characteristics of major mental health and neurodevelopmental diagnoses across the lifespan.
Explain the importance of therapeutic relationship when providing speech pathology services in the mental health and justice setting.

Formulate person- and family-centred management plans to address social, emotional, behavioural, educational and occupational goals for people with communication and swallowing difficulties in the mental health and justice setting.
Reflect on your professional support and supervision needs to work within your scope of practice in the mental health, justice and community setting.

This assessment has been designed to be completed by students after they engage with Module 4 of the Understanding Cultural Safety modules. Students will use a provided with a cultural safety continuum reflective tool and template to develop a professional action plan. They will identify three specific actions they will take to advance their culturally safe practice, and link these actions to the stages of the cultural safety continuum (i.e., unlearning, learning, applying, reflecting, embedding).

In this assignment, students will be introduced to a young person in the justice system with mental health needs. Students will be provided with initial assessment data and asked to develop an easy English assessment report, goal plan, management plan, and session plan. The assignment must be supported by evidence from research literature and show knowledge of the youth justice and mental health context. assessments.assessment_title: Group debate: The value of investment in community-focussed activities
assessments.due_date:
16/12/2025 - 17/12/2025

Debates will take place in the scheduled SPCH7233 Tutorial on Tuesday 16/12/2025.

Students must complete the Buddycheck peer evaluation by 4pm, Wednesday 17/12/2025.
assessments.task_description:
This task will be assessed during tutorial time. It aims to develop students' skills in advocating for community-focussed activities and health promotion and prevention initiatives within speech pathology practice. It aligns with the need for speech pathologists to effectively communicate and influence decision-makers in their workplace.

Part A - Prior to the tutorial in Week 3, groups will be assigned a topic and stance ('for' or 'against') related to community-focused or health promotion and prevention activities. In their group, students will participate in a structured debate with the opposing group assigned to the same topic.

Part B - Following the debate, students will complete a UQ peer evaluation tool, Buddycheck, to demonstrate how each student has contributed to the debate.


The task description and marking criteria will be made available on Blackboard.


When a student is required to complete an oral or practical assessment item worth 20% or more, the performance will be recorded and retained per Appendix 1. (Assessment Procedure (95) ) 


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Online Self-Directed Learning Modules

A recorded course-introduction will be released on the SPCH7233 Blackboard site in O-week. Following this, there will be 1-2 online lecture recordings and associated learning activities will be released each week. These topics will be focussed on the role of speech pathologists in health prevention and promotion and within child, adolescent, and adult mental health and justice systems. It is anticipated that these will take up to 4 hours total per week to complete. Students are required to complete the online learning activities prior to attendance and participation in the weekly tutorials.

learning_activities.topic:
Cultural Safety in Practice Module 4

Students are required to complete Module 3 of the Faculty of Medicine, Health and Behavioural Sciences Cultural Safety in Practice modules, Cultural Safety in Health and Community Services. Module 4 provides an opportunity for students to apply their learning by reflecting on a 'real-life' case study featuring an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person. Each case study incorporates multiple disciplines and encourages students to identify, acknowledge, and analyse their own cultural values; to critically reflect on professional experiences working in an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health setting; and to apply problem-solving skills in analysing scenarios involving Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples’ health and wellbeing.
